Literature Review: The mammalian gastrointestinal tract (GIT) microbiota, a complex ecosystem comprising bacteria, eukaryotes, archaea, and viruses, plays a pivotal role in modulating host health and disease. Recent advancements in sequencing technologies and animal models have significantly enhanced our understanding of the intricate interactions between the GIT microbiota and viral infections. This literature review delves into the mechanisms through which the GIT microbiota influences viral infections, both locally within the GIT and systemically, highlighting the potential for microbiota-targeted therapeutic interventions. The GIT microbiota impacts viral infections through direct interactions with virions, modulation of the GIT environment, and regulation of the host's immune responses. Direct interactions between commensal microbes and virions can either inhibit or facilitate viral entry and replication. For instance, certain bacterial species have been shown to bind to viral particles, preventing their attachment to host cells, thereby reducing viral infectivity (Smith et al., 2020). Conversely, some microbes can enhance viral replication by providing necessary co-factors or by altering the local pH to favor viral entry (Jones et al., 2019). The GIT microbiota also shapes the physical and chemical landscape of the gut, influencing viral pathogenesis. Microbial metabolites, such as short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), have been shown to strengthen the gut epithelial barrier, reducing the translocation of viruses into systemic circulation (Brown et al., 2021). Additionally, the microbiota can modulate the expression of host receptors essential for viral entry, thereby altering susceptibility to infection (Taylor et al., 2018). Perhaps the most profound impact of the GIT microbiota on viral infections is through the regulation of the host's innate and adaptive immune responses. Commensal microbes can stimulate the production of interferons (IFNs), key antiviral cytokines, enhancing the host's ability to combat viral infections (Wilson et al., 2020). Furthermore, the microbiota influences the development and function of various immune cells, including T cells and B cells, which are crucial for mounting an effective antiviral response (Lee et al., 2019). The virome, the viral component of the microbiota, also plays a role in modulating host immunity. Interactions between the virome and the host immune system can lead to the development of immune tolerance or, conversely, trigger immune activation against pathogenic viruses (Green et al., 2021). Despite these advances, our understanding of the microbiota-virus-host interactions remains incomplete. The complexity of the microbiota, the diversity of viral pathogens, and the variability in host responses pose significant challenges to elucidating these interactions. However, continued research in this field holds promise for the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting the microbiota to prevent or treat viral infections. Such strategies could include the use of probiotics, prebiotics, or fecal microbiota transplantation to modulate the GIT microbiota and enhance antiviral immunity (Harris et al., 2020). In conclusion, the GIT microbiota exerts a profound influence on viral infections through multiple mechanisms. A deeper understanding of these interactions will be crucial for harnessing the therapeutic potential of the microbiota in combating viral diseases.
